conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the motion of a particle using a graph of the reciprocal of velocity (1/v) as a function of displacement (x).
The graph shows 1/v (in s·m⁻¹) on the y-axis and x (in m) on the x-axis. The relationship appears to be linear with a positive slope, starting from the origin O and passing through points B and B'.
The reciprocal of velocity (1/v) gives the time taken to travel a unit distance. A larger value of 1/v means a smaller velocity.
Since 1/v increases linearly with x (positive slope), the velocity v decreases as the displacement x increases.

Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. For a particle moving in a straight line: if |v| is decreasing, the particle is decelerating; if |v| is increasing, the particle is accelerating.
The graph shows 1/v (not just the magnitude), so we need to determine the sign of v.
The fact that 1/v is plotted directly (not |1/v|) suggests that v is positive throughout the motion. If v were negative, we would typically see discontinuities or negative values of 1/v.
Since the velocity v is positive and the value of v is decreasing as x increases (because 1/v is increasing), the magnitude of velocity |v| is decreasing with increasing displacement.
The particle is undergoing deceleration. As it moves along the positive x-axis, its velocity remains positive but decreases in magnitude, which means the particle is slowing down.
